question:
what happened to the actor who played frost on rizzoli and isles
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To answer the question, I need to identify the actor who played the character Frost on the television series "Rizzoli & Isles." The character Frost is portrayed by actor Lee Thompson Young. After identifying the actor, I will look into any significant events or news regarding him, particularly focusing on his life after the show and any notable incidents that may have occurred.

Lee Thompson Young tragically passed away in August 2013. His death was ruled a suicide, which shocked many fans and colleagues. Young was known not only for his role in "Rizzoli & Isles" but also for his earlier work in "The Famous Jett Jackson." His passing raised awareness about mental health issues and the pressures faced by individuals in the entertainment industry.

Answer: The actor who played Frost on "Rizzoli & Isles," Lee Thompson Young, tragically passed away in August 2013. His death was ruled a suicide.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
what happened to the actor who played frost on rizzoli and isles

['Ri’chard was considered for the role of Barry Frost in Rizzoli & Isles but the role was given to Lee Thompson Young.\n', 'Swifty Lazar appears as a character in Peter Morgan\'s stage play "Frost/Nixon", first staged at the Donmar Warehouse, London on August 10, 2006 and played by actor Kerry Shale. In the play, Lazar negotiates a deal with David Frost on behalf of President Richard Nixon for Frost to interview Nixon. The play is closely based on real-life events. He was also portrayed by Toby Jones in the 2008 film version of "Frost/Nixon". Swifty Lazar also appeared, thinly disguised as Irving "Sneaky" LaSalle, in George Axelrod\'s 1956 take on Dr. Faustus, the play "Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter" where Sneaky as an agent, will get his clients absolutely anything they want for 10% of their soul. The Lazar role was played on Broadway by Martin Gable.\n', 'Ross\' first television role was as an extra on "The Young and the Restless", which was followed by a small part in "Hill Street Blues" and the male lead in the music video for Whitney Houston\'s 1985 hit song "Saving All My Love for You". He later played Private Ricco Frost in the film "Aliens" (1986), and also appeared in the films "Death Wish 3" (1985), "Spies Like Us" (1985), "" (1985 TV film), "Displaced Person" (1985 episode of "American Playhouse"), "Gulliver\'s Travels" (1996), "" (1996), "Fierce Creatures" (1997), "Nate and the Colonel" (2003) and "Hydra" (2009).\n', 'Zvee Scooler (December 1, 1899 – March 25, 1985) was a Russian-born American actor and radio commentator. He was born in Kamenets-Podolsky (now Ukraine). He performed in both Yiddish and English, on the stage, television, and film. He is probably best known for his roles in "Fiddler on the Roof", playing the innkeeper in the Broadway play and the rabbi in the film version. Another of his more notable roles was that of Boris\' father in Woody Allen\'s "Love and Death".\n', 'BULLET::::- Barold "Barry" Frost (Lee Thompson Young) (Seasons 1–4): Rizzoli\'s second partner. A whiz when it comes to computers and technology, he is terrified of dead bodies and becomes ill at the sight of blood. He is very protective of Jane and stands by her like a loyal, tough partner. In the season five premiere, he is killed off in a car accident while returning from vacation, due in part to the actor\'s death in 2013. In the season five finale, the team establish the Barry Frost Memorial Scholarship, intended for students who are academically gifted and seek to go into professions that would help others but lack the resources to do so.\n', 'On January 20, 2010, Palminteri guested on "Modern Family" and played the same character on the November 2, 2011, episode. Palminteri has reprised the role twice more in season 5. In June 2010, Palminteri began guest-starring on the TNT crime drama "Rizzoli & Isles" as Frank Rizzoli, Sr. He guest starred twice on the CBS drama "Blue Bloods" as Angelo Gallo, a mob lawyer and childhood friend of main character Frank Reagan.\n', 'Joseph Manfredi (portrayed by Ken Marino) is the leader of the Maggia crime syndicate branch in Los Angeles who aids Frost, having previously dated her. He is also an old acquaintance of Howard Stark, and helps Stark and the SSR defeat Frost when she begins losing her mind to the Zero Matter.\n', 'In 1994, Schwimmer was cast as Dr. Ross Geller in NBC\'s situation comedy "Friends", a series that revolved around a group of friends who live near each other in Manhattan. He played a hopeless-romantic paleontologist who works at a museum and later becomes a professor at a university. Schwimmer initially turned down the role as Ross, but accepted later. Executive producer Kevin S. Bright said that he had previously worked with Schwimmer, the character of Ross was written with him in mind, and he was the first actor cast. The show debuted on September 22, 1994, and was watched by almost 22\xa0million American viewers. "Friends" quickly developed a loyal audience, with the show and Schwimmer receiving strong reviews. The "Pittsburgh Post-Gazette" was complimentary of Schwimmer, calling him "terrific". "Variety"\'s television reviewer, said: "All six of the principals, especially (Courteney) Cox and Schwimmer, appear resourceful and display sharp sitcom skills". For this performance, he earned a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series in 1995.\n', 'Ricco Ross originally read for the part of Corporal Hicks. He was then offered the role of Private Drake, but he turned it down in favour of appearing in "Full Metal Jacket". However, James Cameron was so impressed with Ross\' audition that he wrote the character of Frost specifically for him, and as a result Ross left Kubrick\'s production to appear in Aliens. In a 2014 interview for the podcast "I Was There Too", Ross stated that Private Frost\'s first name is actually Robert.\n', 'Mmoloki Chrystie is an English actor, probably best recognised for playing the football-crazed, not-too-bright Frazer "Frazz" Davis in the BAFTA award-winning Central Television / Children\'s ITV comedy-drama "Press Gang". Prior to that, Chrystie had played Kevin Baylon in another children\'s favourite, "Grange Hill", from 1984–1987. Kevin was best friend of \'Zammo\' McGuire (Lee MacDonald), and so featured heavily in the infamous Zammo "Just Say No" drugs storyline and campaign.\n']

He is probably best known for his roles in "Fiddler on the Roof", playing the innkeeper in the Broadway play and the rabbi in the film version. Another of his more notable roles was that of Boris' father in Woody Allen's "Love and Death".
', 'BULLET::::- Barold "Barry" Frost (Lee Thompson Young) (Seasons 1–4): Rizzoli's second partner. A whiz when it comes to computers and technology, he is terrified of dead bodies and becomes ill at the sight of blood. He is very protective of Jane and stands by her like a loyal, tough partner. In the season five premiere, he is killed off in a car accident while returning from vacation, due in part to the actor's death in 2013. In the season five finale, the team establish the Barry Frost Memorial Scholarship, intended for students who are academically gifted and seek to go into professions that would help others but lack the resources to do so.
', 'On January 20, 2010, Palminteri guested on "Modern Family" and played the same character on the November 2, 2011, episode. Palminteri has reprised the role twice more in season 5. In June 2010, Palminteri began guest-starring on the TNT crime drama "Rizzoli & Isles" as Frank Rizzoli, Sr. He guest starred twice on the CBS drama "Blue Bloods" as Angelo Gallo, a mob lawyer and childhood friend of main character Frank Reagan.
', 'Joseph Manfredi (portrayed by Ken Marino) is the leader of the Maggia crime syndicate branch in Los Angeles who aids Frost, having previously dated her. He is also an old acquaintance of Howard Stark, and helps Stark and the SSR defeat Frost when she begins losing her mind to the Zero Matter.
', 'In 1994, Schwimmer was cast as Dr. Ross Geller in NBC's situation comedy "Friends", a series that revolved around a group of friends who live near each other in Manhattan. He played a hopeless-romantic paleontologist who works at a museum and later becomes a professor at a university. Schwimmer initially turned down the role as Ross, but accepted later. Executive producer Kevin S. Bright said that he had previously worked with Schwimmer, the character of Ross was written with him in mind, and he was the first actor cast. The show debuted on September 22, 1994, and was watched by almost 22\xa0million American viewers. "Friends" quickly developed a loyal audience, with the show and Schwimmer receiving strong reviews. The "Pittsburgh Post-Gazette" was complimentary of Schwimmer, calling him "terrific". "Variety"'s television reviewer, said: "All six of the principals, especially (Courteney) Cox and Schwimmer, appear resourceful and display sharp sitcom skills". For this performance, he earned a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series in 1995.
', 'Ricco Ross originally read for the part of Corporal Hicks. He was then offered the role of Private Drake, but he turned it down in favour of appearing in "Full Metal Jacket". However, James Cameron was so impressed with Ross' audition that he wrote the character of Frost specifically for him, and as a result Ross left Kubrick's production to appear in Aliens. In a 2014 interview for the podcast "I Was There Too", Ross stated that Private Frost's first name is actually Robert.
', 'Mmoloki Chrystie is an English actor, probably best recognised for playing the football-crazed, not-too-bright Frazer "Frazz" Davis in the BAFTA award-winning Central Television / Children's ITV comedy-drama "Press Gang". Prior to that, Chrystie had played Kevin Baylon in another children's favourite, "Grange Hill", from 1984–1987. Kevin was best friend of 'Zammo' McGuire (Lee MacDonald), and so featured heavily in the infamous Zammo "Just Say No" drugs storyline and campaign.
']

2. **Significant Life Events**:
   - Young's tragic death in August 2013 is a crucial event. His death was ruled a suicide, which shocked many in the entertainment industry and his fanbase. This event is significant not only for its impact on the show but also for the broader conversation it sparked regarding mental health issues in Hollywood.

3. **Impact on the Show**:
   - Following Young's death, the character Barry Frost was written out of the show. In the season five premiere, the character was killed off in a car accident while returning from vacation. This narrative decision reflects a direct causal link between the actor's real-life circumstances and the storyline of the series.

4. **Legacy and Memorialization**:
   - The establishment of the Barry Frost Memorial Scholarship in the season five finale serves as a poignant tribute to Young. This scholarship is intended for academically gifted students who aspire to help others but lack the resources to do so. This illustrates how the show creators chose to honor Young's legacy and the impact of his death on the narrative and the community.

5. **Broader Implications**:

The actor who played Frost on "Rizzoli & Isles," Lee Thompson Young, tragically passed away in August 2013. His death was ruled a suicide, which shocked many fans and colleagues. Following his passing, the character Barry Frost was killed off in the show due to the actor's death. In his memory, the series established the Barry Frost Memorial Scholarship, aimed at supporting academically gifted students who wish to pursue careers that help others but lack the necessary resources.
